  • client sponsor, vendor PM, tech lead, team members, band members, yourself.

Participants can have different levels of power, risk, and ability to speak freely.

docs.title: Power and Safety
docs.text:
Short-hand for:

  • who has more formal or informal authority,
  • who is more exposed to risk (job, contract, reputation, health),
  • how safe it is to speak honestly in this space.

QSS treats power and safety as structural facts, not personal flaws. They affect:

  • which questions are safe to ask,
  • how Emotion & Needs is phrased,
  • and how Meta questions are used.

docs.title: Scope and Limits
docs.text:
The boundaries of what a question space is meant to handle.

QSS is designed for:

  • reflection,
  • alignment,
  • sense-making,
  • decision support in work and creative contexts.

QSS is not designed for:

  • emergency situations,
  • diagnosis or treatment (medical or mental health),
  • legal advice or disputes,
  • deep therapeutic processing of trauma.

When a space touches these areas, the responsible move is to:

  • stop or lighten the inquiry,
  • and consider redirecting to appropriate support.

docs.title: Dimensions of Inquiry
docs.text: These are the main “lenses” you can activate in a topology.

docs.title: Clarification
docs.text:
Goal:

  • align on meaning and basic facts.

Used for:

  • “What are we even talking about?”
  • “What problem are we trying to solve?”

Typical questions:

  • “In your own words, what is this about?”
  • “What does this term mean to you?”

docs.title: Assumptions
docs.text:
Goal:

  • surface what is taken for granted but not stated.

Used for:

  • uncovering hidden expectations,
  • explaining repeated surprises or disappointments.

Typical questions:

  • “What were you expecting that we never said out loud?”
  • “What are we treating as fixed that might not be?”

docs.title: Boundaries and Ownership
docs.text:
Goal:

  • define scope, responsibilities, and decision rights.

Used for:

  • clarifying who decides what,
  • reducing “work that falls between chairs”,
  • limiting over-responsibility.

Typical questions:

  • “Who owns this decision?”
  • “Where do handoffs feel risky or unclear?”

docs.title: Value and Impact
docs.text:
Goal:

  • understand what matters and for whom.

Used for:

  • aligning priorities,
  • making trade-offs visible.

Typical questions:

  • “Who is most affected if this goes well or badly?”
  • “What does success look like, and for whom?”

docs.title: Emotional and Relational Field / Needs
docs.text:
Goal:

  • make the felt experience and basic needs visible enough to design responsibly.

Used for:

  • situations with tension, fatigue, enthusiasm, or fear,
  • aligning collaboration with human needs.

Constraints:

  • stays in the context of this work/relationship/creative project and near future,
  • avoids deep clinical or therapeutic work.

Typical questions:

  • “How does this collaboration feel right now?”
  • “Which of your needs are clearly met or not met here?”

docs.title: Contrast and Alternatives
docs.text:
Goal:

  • compare options and highlight trade-offs.

Used for:

  • avoiding false binaries,
  • mapping different plausible paths.

Typical questions:

  • “What are the main paths we see?”
  • “What does each path give and cost us?”

docs.title: Causality and Consequence
docs.text:
Goal:

  • connect causes and effects, especially in recurring patterns.

Used for:

  • understanding why certain dynamics repeat,
  • anticipating consequences of choices.

Typical questions:

  • “What usually happens next when this pattern starts?”
  • “If we choose this option, what likely chain of events follows?”

docs.title: Layering / Abstraction
docs.text:
Goal:

  • move between levels of detail and system views.

Used for:

  • keeping conversations from getting stuck in tiny details or vague generalities.

Typical questions:

  • “At the high level, what are we trying to do?”
  • “Can you give one concrete example of that?”

docs.title: Temporal
docs.text:
Goal:

  • use time as a lens (past, present, future).

Used for:

  • spotting trends,
  • imagining consequences,
  • extracting lessons.

Typical questions:

  • “When did this start?”
  • “If nothing changes in six or twelve months, how will that feel?”

docs.title: Evidence and Uncertainty
docs.text:
Goal:

  • distinguish what is known from what is guessed,
  • gauge confidence and risk.

Used for:

  • any decision with stakes,
  • correcting overconfident narratives.

Typical questions:

  • “What do we actually know from data or experience?”
  • “What are we assuming, and how could we be wrong?”
  • “What experiment would reduce our uncertainty?”

docs.title: Meta / Reflexive
docs.text:
Goal:

  • reflect on the space itself and how it is working.

Used for:

  • recursion,
  • co-steering the conversation.

Typical questions:

  • “What feels useful or not useful about this conversation?”
  • “Have we named the real issue, or are we circling?”

docs.title: Shallow Pass
docs.text:
A first light pass over multiple dimensions:

  • one or two questions per dimension,
  • to see where the energy or problem really is.

Often followed by a deep dive into one or two dimensions.

docs.title: Deep Dive
docs.text:
Focused exploration of a specific dimension:

  • used after a shallow pass reveals where the leverage is,
  • or when entering a space with a very clear problem area.

docs.title: Branching Flow
docs.text:
A flow with conditional paths:

  • Core trunk:
  • a few questions you always ask.
  • Branches:
  • additional questions you use only if certain signals appear:
    • strong disagreement,
    • visible frustration,
    • conflicting facts.

docs.title: Ladder Flow
docs.text:
A deliberate alternation between:

  • abstract questions (principles, patterns, big picture),
  • concrete questions (examples, specific incidents).

Used to avoid getting stuck at only one level.

docs.title: Funnel Flow
docs.text:
A pattern that moves from:

  • wide exploration of values and options,
  • through analysis of consequences and evidence,
  • toward narrower commitment and next steps.

docs.title: Setup Mode
docs.text:
You are:

  • designing or initiating something new,
  • trying to prevent obvious misalignment,
  • setting expectations and boundaries.

Key dimensions often include:

  • Clarification,
  • Assumptions,
  • Boundaries & Ownership,
  • Value & Impact,
  • Evidence & Uncertainty.

docs.title: Stabilization Mode
docs.text:
You are:

  • dealing with drift, conflict, or tension,
  • trying to stop things from getting worse,
  • aiming for small stabilizing moves.

Key dimensions often include:

  • Clarification,
  • Temporal,
  • Assumptions,
  • Boundaries & Ownership,
  • Emotion & Needs,
  • Value & Impact,
  • Evidence & Uncertainty.

docs.title: Growth Mode
docs.text:
You are:

  • improving something that already basically works,
  • exploring options and trade-offs,
  • designing experiments or long-term direction.

Key dimensions often include:

  • Value & Impact,
  • Contrast & Alternatives,
  • Temporal,
  • Causality & Consequence,
  • Layering,
  • Evidence & Uncertainty,
  • Meta.

docs.title: Domain-Specific Terms (as used in Playbooks)
docs.text: These are not universal definitions; they are how QSS uses them in the domain playbooks.

docs.title: Client–Vendor Engagement
docs.text:
Any relationship where:

  • one party buys or commissions work,
  • the other delivers services or products.

In QSS:

  • often a focus area for Setup and Stabilization spaces,
  • with explicit attention to power, contracts, and expectations.

docs.title: DevEx (Developer Experience)
docs.text:
The lived experience of engineers in an organization:

  • tools,
  • processes,
  • culture,
  • cognitive load,
  • ability to do good work without excessive friction.

In QSS:

  • often a Growth-mode topic in delivery/consulting playbooks.

docs.title: Band Identity
docs.text:
The shared sense of:

  • what a band or musical project sounds like,
  • what it stands for,
  • what listeners can expect.

In QSS:

  • a focus area for creative Growth-mode spaces (music playbook).

docs.title: Mixing Direction
docs.text:
The deliberate choice of:

  • sonic aesthetic,
  • balance between raw/live vs polished/studio,
  • intended listening context.

In QSS:

  • often explored via Contrast & Alternatives, Value & Impact, Emotion & Needs.

docs.title: Emotional Scope
docs.text:
The intended depth of emotional exploration:

  • present-focused,
  • context-bound (work, collaboration, creative project),
  • near-term future.

QSS does not aim to process:

  • deep childhood history,
  • trauma,
  • or clinical conditions.

docs.title: Red Flags
docs.text:
Signals that QSS should step back and other support should step in:

  • risk of harm or self-harm,
  • serious health symptoms,
  • legal threats or disputes,
  • abuse or harassment.

When these appear, the appropriate move is to:

  • pause or limit the question space,
  • acknowledge the weight,
  • suggest or seek more suitable help.

You do not need to memorize any of this.

The glossary is here so that when a term appears in Theory, Practice, or examples, you can quickly:

  • check what it means in this system,
  • and decide how you want to adapt it in your own Question Space System.

docs.title: Question Pattern Cheatsheets
docs.text:
This file is meant as a grab-and-go reference.

You already know the ideas from Theory and Practice. Here you get ready-made question patterns grouped by:

  • Dimension cheatsheets (Clarification, Assumptions, etc.)
  • Mode cheatsheets (Setup, Stabilization, Growth)
  • Micro-patterns (entries, meta, closures, safety pivots)

Use it to:

  • draft a space quickly,
  • adjust phrasing on the fly,
  • or un-stick a stalled conversation.

You are expected to adapt wording to your own voice.

docs.title: Dimension Cheatsheets
docs.text:
Each dimension has:

  • Light – low-intensity, safe in most contexts
  • Standard – typical usage
  • Deep – only when trust, time, and scope allow
  • Power-aware tweaks – for strong hierarchy / risk

docs.title: Clarification
docs.text:
Goal: align on “what we’re talking about” and basic facts.

Light:

  • “In your own words, what is this about?”
  • “If you had to explain this in one sentence to a colleague, what would you say?”
  • “What decision or problem is actually on the table right now?”

Standard:

  • “What is happening, from your perspective?”
  • “What would you say is inside the scope of this discussion, and what is clearly outside?”
  • “What has already been tried so far?”

Deep:

  • “If we rewound to the start of this situation, what would we describe differently than we did back then?”
  • “What parts of this are noise, and what is the real signal we should focus on?”

Power-aware tweaks:

  • Emphasize perspective:
  • “From your vantage point, what does this look like?”
  • Avoid framing someone as “wrong” from the start:
  • use “different views” instead of “misunderstandings”.

When to avoid:

  • When people are in clear distress; start with emotional safety first.

docs.title: Assumptions
docs.text:
Goal: surface expectations and beliefs that were never stated.

Light:

  • “What were you expecting would happen here?”
  • “What did you assume the other side would do?”
  • “What did you assume you would get from this?”

Standard:

  • “Which expectations did we never actually say out loud?”
  • “What are we treating as fixed that might not be?”
  • “What story are we telling ourselves about why the other side behaves like this?”

Deep:

  • “If your main assumptions were wrong, what would change in how you see this situation?”
  • “Which assumptions are protecting you from discomfort, and which are actually helping you see clearly?”

Power-aware tweaks:

  • Own your side first:
  • “Here’s what I realized I was assuming. What about you?”
  • Use “we” and “our” more than “you” when power is unequal.

When to avoid:

  • When someone is being blamed in front of their boss; start with Clarification and Value first.

docs.title: Boundaries and Ownership
docs.text:
Goal: clarify who owns what and where responsibilities begin and end.

Light:

  • “Who is supposed to decide this?”
  • “Where does your responsibility end in this process?”
  • “Where do you see the riskiest handoffs?”

Standard:

  • “For each of these areas, who owns decisions, who executes, and who needs to be informed?”
  • “Are there decisions that both sides think they own?”
  • “Is there anything important that currently nobody clearly owns?”

Deep:

  • “Where are you carrying responsibility that was never formally given to you?”
  • “What would a healthier boundary look like here, in concrete terms?”

Power-aware tweaks:

  • Invite shared ownership:
  • “Let’s map responsibilities, not blame. I’ll start with what I think I own.”
  • Be careful not to turn this into “who failed”; keep it about design of roles.

When to avoid:

  • When legal responsibility is actively disputed; switch to legal/contract processes.

docs.title: Value and Impact
docs.text:
Goal: understand what matters, for whom, and why.

Light:

  • “Who is most affected by this?”
  • “What would a good outcome look like for you?”
  • “What do you really want from this situation?”

Standard:

  • “If we cannot get everything, what is most important to protect?”
  • “Whose success are we optimizing for here?”
  • “What would make this clearly worth the effort for you?”

Deep:

  • “If you look three to five years ahead, what impact do you hope this choice will have?”
  • “What impact do you fear it could have if it goes badly?”

Power-aware tweaks:

  • Center their interests when you hold more power:
  • “From your side, what outcome would make this feel worthwhile?”
  • Validate multiple stakeholders:
  • “I know this affects not just you, but also X and Y. How do you weigh those?”

When to avoid:

  • Almost never; but in acute crisis, safety and stabilization come first.

docs.title: Emotional and Relational Field / Needs
docs.text:
Goal: acknowledge how the situation feels and what basic needs are affected, within context and scope.

Light:

  • “Right now, does this setup feel more supportive or more draining for you?”
  • “What has been most frustrating or tiring about this?”
  • “What keeps you still engaged here, despite the difficulties?”

Standard:

  • “Which of your needs feel met in this collaboration (for example, respect, clarity, belonging, autonomy)? Which do not?”
  • “Was there a moment where your trust dipped? What happened?”
  • “What would make this feel more sustainable or respectful for you?”

Deep:

  • “What have you been holding back saying about how this feels?”
  • “What is this situation doing to your energy and confidence over time?”

Power-aware tweaks:

  • Shift to system language:
  • “What about our setup makes it harder for you to do good work?”
  • Start with yourself if you have power:
  • “Here is where I think my actions may have made this feel worse. I’d like to hear how this has been for you.”

When to avoid:

  • When discussion is sliding into trauma, self-harm, or deep family issues:
  • acknowledge, then redirect to more appropriate support.

docs.title: Contrast and Alternatives
docs.text:
Goal: lay out options and see trade-offs more clearly.

Light:

  • “What are the main options you see right now?”
  • “If we name two extremes, what are they?”
  • “What is the ‘safe’ path and what is the ‘bold’ path?”

Standard:

  • “For each option, what do we gain and what do we lose?”
  • “Which option gives the best trade-off between risk and impact, given our constraints?”
  • “Is there a hybrid or third option we are ignoring?”

Deep:

  • “If we imagine that all options fail, which failure do we prefer?”
  • “Which option would we choose if we optimized for long-term integrity rather than short-term comfort?”

Power-aware tweaks:

  • Ask them to define options first, especially if you hold power:
  • “Before I share my view, what options do you see?”
  • Avoid pushing your preferred option as a “neutral question”.

When to avoid:

  • When people are in acute distress and need stabilization more than choice architecture.

docs.title: Causality and Consequence
docs.text:
Goal: make cause–effect chains and likely outcomes explicit.

Light:

  • “What usually happens next when this pattern starts?”
  • “What do you think this decision will change in the next few weeks?”
  • “Who will notice the impact first?”

Standard:

  • “What is the most plausible chain of events if we continue as we are?”
  • “If we choose option A, walk me through the likely next three steps.”
  • “What unintended consequences should we be watching for?”

Deep:

  • “If this pattern continues for a year, what does the system look like then?”
  • “What structural forces are keeping this pattern in place?”

Power-aware tweaks:

  • Talk about systems, not individuals:
  • “How does our current process produce this outcome, even when people are trying their best?”

When to avoid:

  • When someone is being blamed for systemic issues; first reframe the problem at system level.

docs.title: Layering / Abstraction
docs.text:
Goal: move flexibly between detail and big picture.

Light:

  • “At a high level, what are we trying to do here?”
  • “Can you give one concrete example of that?”
  • “Is this a local issue or a pattern you see in many places?”

Standard:

  • “How does this specific situation reflect something larger in our system?”
  • “If we fix this incident but not the pattern, what happens?”

Deep:

  • “At which level should we actually intervene: individual, team, process, organization, ecosystem?”
  • “What would change if we shifted this one level up or down?”

Power-aware tweaks:

  • Use layering to protect individuals:
  • “Instead of focusing on this person, can we describe the pattern they’re caught in?”

When to avoid:

  • When people are overwhelmed; too much zooming can feel abstract and evasive.

docs.title: Temporal
docs.text:
Goal: use time (past, present, future) to understand and design.

Light:

  • “When did this start?”
  • “What has changed since then?”
  • “If nothing changes for the next six months, how do you expect to feel?”

Standard:

  • “Looking back, when did things feel most ‘right’? What was true then?”
  • “If this goes well in one to three years, what is true?”
  • “If it goes badly, what is the plausible ‘bad case’?”

Deep:

  • “Which decisions in the past created the current constraints?”
  • “What future are we silently committing to if we keep our current habits?”

Power-aware tweaks:

  • Avoid using the past to blame; use it to learn:
  • “Given what we know now, what would we do differently next time?”

When to avoid:

  • When someone is stuck in regret loops; stay closer to present and near-future steps.

docs.title: Evidence and Uncertainty
docs.text:
Goal: separate what is known from what is guessed, and assess confidence.

Light:

  • “What do we actually know about this?”
  • “What are we assuming?”
  • “How confident are we, roughly, on a scale from 1 to 10?”

Standard:

  • “What data, history, or concrete examples support this view?”
  • “Where are we acting as if we know, but really we’re guessing?”
  • “What experiment or test could reduce our uncertainty?”

Deep:

  • “Where are we clinging to a story because it’s comfortable, despite weak evidence?”
  • “If we had to bet our own money or reputation on this assumption, would we still hold it?”

Power-aware tweaks:

  • Avoid turning this into cross-examination of lower-power people:
  • focus on shared assumptions:
    • “What are we, as a group, treating as fact without proof?”

When to avoid:

  • When evidence depends on medical, legal, or clinical expertise you don’t have; recognize limits and involve appropriate professionals.

docs.title: Meta / Reflexive
docs.text:
Goal: let the conversation reflect on itself and adjust.

Light:

  • “How is this conversation landing so far?”
  • “What has been most useful so far? Least useful?”
  • “Is there anything we’re avoiding talking about?”

Standard:

  • “Did any question feel unfair or unsafe?”
  • “Have we named the real issue, or are we still circling?”
  • “What should we do differently if we run a similar conversation again?”

Deep:

  • “What does our difficulty talking about this reveal about our system?”
  • “What kind of conversations do we never allow ourselves to have?”

Power-aware tweaks:

  • Start by owning your side:
  • “Has my way of asking questions helped or made this harder?”
  • Give explicit permission to critique the space:
  • “It’s okay if you say this wasn’t helpful; that’s data.”

When to avoid:

  • Rarely needed; but don’t overdo Meta in crisis moments—people may need concrete support more than process reflection.

docs.title: Mode Cheatsheets
docs.text: Short patterns for Setup, Stabilization, and Growth.

docs.title: Setup Mode Cheatsheet
docs.text:
Use when:

  • starting engagements,
  • defining collaborations,
  • before things go wrong.

Recommended dimensions:

  • Clarification
  • Value & Impact
  • Assumptions
  • Boundaries & Ownership
  • Evidence & Uncertainty
  • light Emotional & Needs
  • Meta

Pattern (30–60 minutes):

  1. Clarify
  2. “In your own words, what are we here to make happen?”
  3. Value
  4. “What does success look like for you?”
  5. Assumptions
  6. “What are you expecting from us that we haven’t explicitly discussed?”
  7. Boundaries
  8. “Which decisions do you expect us to own, and which do you want to own?”
  9. Evidence
  10. “What do we know from similar situations, and where are we guessing?”
  11. Emotion (light)
  12. “What would make this collaboration feel predictable and respectful for you?”
  13. Meta
  14. “What feels clearer? Any concerns still invisible?”

docs.title: Stabilization Mode Cheatsheet
docs.text:
Use when:

  • things are wobbling,
  • people are frustrated,
  • slips or conflicts are visible.

Recommended dimensions:

  • Clarification
  • Temporal
  • Assumptions
  • Boundaries & Ownership
  • Emotional & Needs
  • Value & Impact
  • Evidence & Uncertainty
  • Meta

Pattern (45–60 minutes):

  1. Clarify through stories
  2. “From your perspective, what’s been happening?”
  3. Temporal
  4. “When did things start to feel off? What changed around then?”
  5. Emotion & Needs
  6. “What has been most frustrating or draining for you?”
  7. Assumptions
  8. “What did you expect would happen that didn’t?”
  9. Boundaries
  10. “Where was ownership or decision-making unclear?”
  11. Evidence
  12. “What do we actually know versus what we’re assuming?”
  13. Value
  14. “What is most important to protect going forward?”
  15. Meta and small reset
  16. “One concrete change we’ll try next. What about this conversation should we repeat or change?”

docs.title: Growth Mode Cheatsheet
docs.text:
Use when:

  • things basically work,
  • you want to improve, deepen, or choose direction.

Recommended dimensions:

  • Value & Impact
  • Contrast & Alternatives
  • Causality & Consequence
  • Temporal
  • Layering
  • Evidence & Uncertainty
  • Emotional & Needs (positive)
  • Meta

Pattern (60–90 minutes):

  1. Value
  2. “What are we trying to maximize over the next one to three years?”
  3. Temporal (future)
  4. “If this goes well, what is true in three years?”
  5. Contrast
  6. “What are the main paths we see?”
  7. Causality
  8. “For each path, what is the most plausible chain of events?”
  9. Layering
  10. “How does each path affect individuals, team, and system?”
  11. Evidence
  12. “What do we know from past experience? Where are we guessing?”
  13. Emotion (positive)
  14. “Which path feels like the kind of effort and impact we want in our lives?”
  15. Meta and bets
  16. “What small bets or experiments do we commit to now?”

docs.title: Micro-Pattern Cheatsheets
docs.text: Fast patterns you can drop into any space.

docs.title: Entry patterns
docs.text:
Neutral:

  • “Can we each give a one-sentence version of what we think this is about?”
  • “Before we dive in, what outcome would make this time well spent for you?”

Tense situations:

  • “I can see this is not easy. Before we try to fix anything, can we first make sure we see the situation in a similar way?”
  • “I’d like to understand how this has been for you, in your own words.”

Solo reflection:

  • “What do I need this time to help me with?”
  • “If this reflection went well, what would I walk away clearer about?”

docs.title: Pivot patterns (when things go sideways)
docs.text:
Too emotional / hot:

  • “This feels intense. Let’s pause for a moment. What part of this is most important to keep talking about, and what can wait?”

Too abstract:

  • “Can we anchor this in one concrete recent example?”
  • “Where did this show up last week?”

Too detailed / in the weeds:

  • “If we zoom out, what is the bigger pattern this example belongs to?”
  • “At the highest level, what are we actually trying to achieve?”

docs.title: Meta patterns
docs.text:
Mid-session check:

  • “Is this line of questioning still helpful, or do we need to shift?”
  • “Have we named the real issue, or are we still circling around it?”

End-session check:

  • “What feels clearer now?”
  • “What is still foggy?”
  • “What is one next step you are willing to take, based on this?”

docs.title: Safety and scope patterns
docs.text:
When you hit something out-of-scope (medical, legal, deep trauma):

  • “This sounds heavier than what this space is designed to hold.”
  • “I don’t want to pretend questions alone can handle this. It might be better to talk to [doctor / therapist / lawyer / HR / trusted person] about that part.”
  • “We can stay with the work/creative context here, and treat the other part as a separate concern.”

When you sense distress:

  • “I’m noticing this is bringing up a lot. Do you want to keep going a bit, slow down, or pause and pick this up another time?”
  • “We don’t have to answer everything today. What feels safe enough to stay with, and what should we park for now?”

docs.title: “One small step” patterns
docs.text:
Use these to land the space in action.

Work/consulting:

  • “Given everything we discussed, what is one small change we can test in the next one to two weeks?”
  • “What will we stop doing immediately because it clearly makes things worse?”

Personal reflection:

  • “What is one low-risk step I can take this week that respects what I learned here?”
  • “What conversation do I need to schedule, and with whom?”

Music/creative:

  • “What is one specific change we’ll try in the next rehearsal/mix?”
  • “What do we want to listen for after we make that change?”

You do not have to use these verbatim.

The point of these cheatsheets is to give you shapes and starting points so you can design and adapt question spaces quickly, without losing:

  • orientation,
  • power-awareness,
  • emotional scope,
  • and a clear way to land in the next step.

docs.title: Example Question Spaces and Case Studies
docs.text:
This file shows full examples of question spaces in action.

Each example includes:

  • Context snapshot – what was going on.
  • Orientation – how the space was defined.
  • Topology – which dimensions were chosen and why.
  • Flow sketch – how the conversation actually unfolded.
  • Recursion notes – what was learned and how the space changed.

Treat these as worked examples you can adapt, not universal recipes.

docs.title: Case 1 – Client–Vendor Reset for a Slipping Fixed-Bid Project
Context snapshot
docs.text:
• Domain: software delivery, consulting.
  • Situation:
  • Fixed-bid project, mid-way through.
  • Delivery slipping; client threatening escalation but not yet cancelling.
  • Vendor team tired; client sponsor under pressure from their leadership.
  • Format: 60-minute remote call, client and vendor leaders only.
  • Stakes: high (reputation, budget, relationship).

docs.title: Orientation
docs.text:
“In this Stabilization situation, with the client holding commercial power and the vendor under delivery and margin pressure, I want this space to help us:

  • get a shared picture of what has been happening,
  • surface expectations and boundaries,
  • and agree on one or two stabilizing changes,

in a way that is honest but non-blaming, within a 60-minute joint call, staying in work context (no legal negotiation, no therapy).”

Cognitive goals:

  • shared understanding of drift causes,
  • agreement on minimal reset actions.

Relational goals:

  • de-escalate tension,
  • restore some sense of predictability.

docs.title: Topology
docs.text:
Chosen dimensions:

  • Clarification – necessary; both sides have different stories.
  • Temporal – to pinpoint when things went off.
  • Assumptions – hidden expectations are driving frustration.
  • Boundaries & Ownership – unclear roles on scope/timeline decisions.
  • Emotional & Relational Field / Needs – frustration and fatigue are visible.
  • Value & Impact – to anchor on what still matters most.
  • Evidence & Uncertainty – to separate stories from facts.
  • Meta / Reflexive – to adjust in the moment and check usefulness.

Why this set:

  • Stabilization mode → this is the “standard” stabilization topology.
  • Emotion is not optional; but phrased at collaboration level, not personal therapy.
  • Evidence is needed because both sides have “we always…” narratives.

docs.title: Flow sketch (what actually happened)
docs.text:
Entry – Clarification

  • Q: “From your perspective, what has been happening with this project over the last six weeks?” Client speaks first; vendor listens and reflects back.
  • Q: “From our side, here is how the last six weeks looked. What’s different or missing?”

Result:

  • Two different timelines appear (client focusing on missed milestones; vendor focusing on dependency delays).

Temporal and assumptions

  • Q: “If you look back, when did this start to feel ‘off’ for you?” Client points to a mid-project scope extension; vendor points to an internal client re-org.
  • Q: “At those moments, what were you expecting we would do? What did you think we expected from you?”

Result:

  • Client assumed vendor would absorb scope with minor adjustment.
  • Vendor assumed client would extend timeline before approving extra scope.

Boundaries and ownership

  • Q: “Who did we think owned:
  • scope change approvals,
  • timeline changes,
  • cutting or deferring requirements?”
  • Q: “Are there decisions that both of us thought we owned?”

Result:

  • Scope decisions effectively had no clear owner; both parties thought the other would concede.

Emotion and needs (context-limited)

  • Q: “How does this collaboration feel for you right now: more predictable or more draining?” Client: “draining and unpredictable.” Vendor: “tense and reactive.”
  • Q: “What would need to change for this to feel workable again over the next month or two?”

Result:

  • Client needs predictability and fewer last-minute surprises.
  • Vendor needs clearer decisions and realistic trade-offs.

Evidence and uncertainty

  • Q: “What do we actually know from data or events about:
  • how much scope increased,
  • when key decisions were made,
  • where time was lost?”
  • Q: “Where are we guessing or blaming without data?”

Result:

  • A few concrete facts surface:
  • ~25% scope increase with no timeline change.
  • Multiple weeks lost awaiting approvals.
  • Both admit to narratives that weren’t fully grounded.

Value and impact

  • Q: “Given where we are, what’s most important to protect:
  • the ultimate feature list,
  • the original date,
  • relationship and future work,
  • or team sustainability?”
  • Q: “If we cannot have everything, what are you most willing to trade off?”

Result:

  • Client: willing to trim scope; very sensitive to losing credibility on date.
  • Vendor: willing to push harder in short term if scope is reduced and change rules are clear.

Exit – minimal reset and Meta

  • Q: “What one or two concrete changes can we commit to for the next four weeks?”
  • Joint decision:
    • scope triage workshop within one week,
    • clear RACI for scope and timeline changes,
    • weekly 30-minute “no surprises” sync.
  • Q: “What felt useful about this conversation, and what should we adjust next time?”

Result:

  • Client: “This is the first time I feel we’re actually talking about the real issues, not just status.”
  • Vendor: “We should have done this earlier; we were avoiding hard scope conversations.”

docs.title: Recursion notes
docs.text:
What worked:

  • Early multi-perspective Clarification exposed divergent timelines without blame.
  • Emotion & Needs, phrased around collaboration, helped name fatigue safely.
  • Boundaries segment revealed “no owner” decisions.

What felt off:

  • Time pressure: Evidence & Uncertainty felt rushed.
  • The session almost drifted into renegotiation of contract terms.

Space changes (v1.1):

  • For future escalations:
  • Add a very brief “contract is not being renegotiated here” scope statement in Orientation.
  • Move Value & Impact earlier so reset actions are anchored faster.
  • Prepare a one-page visual timeline beforehand to save time in Clarification.

The space evolved from:

  • “Escalation Reset v1.0” to
  • “Escalation Reset – Scope and Stability v1.1”.

docs.title: Case 2 – Internal Team Retro After a Rough Release
Context snapshot
docs.text:
• Domain: internal software team.
  • Situation:
  • Release caused late nights, bugs, and internal tension.
  • Standard retros drift into “we should communicate more” without change.
  • Format: 45-minute retro, whole team + manager.
  • Stakes: medium (team morale, future releases).

docs.title: Orientation
docs.text:
“In this Stabilization retro, with the team tired but still functioning, I want this space to help us understand what made this release painful, and agree on one or two changes that make the next release less brutal, within 45 minutes, staying on team processes and behaviors (no performance reviews, no personal attacks).”

Cognitive goals:

  • identify one or two structural causes,
  • design minimal process changes.

Relational goals:

  • legitimize people’s tiredness,
  • avoid blame spirals.

docs.title: Topology
docs.text:
Dimensions:

  • Clarification – avoid vague “bad release” talk.
  • Emotional & Relational Field / Needs – burnout risk; must be visible.
  • Assumptions – mismatch on expectations.
  • Boundaries & Ownership – unclear decisions around scope and testing.
  • Evidence & Uncertainty – distinguish actual incidents from perceptions.
  • Value & Impact – re-anchor on what matters next time.
  • Meta – small review at end.

docs.title: Flow sketch (key moments)
docs.text:
Clarification

  • Q: “In one or two sentences each, what made this release ‘rough’ for you?” Team members share short statements:
  • “constant scope changes,”
  • “nightly fixes,”
  • “unrealistic date.”
  • Facilitator clusters themes on a board: scope volatility, late testing, last-minute decisions.

Emotion & Needs

  • Q: “On a scale 1–10, how supported did you feel during this release?” Numbers cluster around 4–6.
  • Q: “What is one thing that made this number lower than you’d like?” Answers:
  • unplanned weekend work,
  • unclear priority changes,
  • lack of backup.

Assumptions

  • Q: “What did you expect others would do that they did not do (and we never explicitly agreed on)?” Examples:
  • devs expected PMs to reject late scope,
  • PMs expected devs to push back sooner.

Boundaries & Ownership

  • Q: “For scope changes inside the last two weeks before release, who owns accept/reject decisions?” Silence → realization that nobody was explicit owner.
  • Q: “Who decides to slip date vs cut scope?”
  • Team assumed “business”.
  • Manager assumed “joint” but hadn’t set a clear rule.

Evidence & Uncertainty

  • Q: “How many scope changes landed after code freeze date?” They check board: multiple.
  • Q: “How many incidents did we actually ship to production?” Fewer than the emotional memory suggested; intensity was due to timing and tiredness.

Value & Impact

  • Q: “For the next release, what matters most:
  • fewer nights/weekend work,
  • fewer incidents,
  • more predictable scope?”
  • They choose:
  • more predictable scope,
  • fewer nights/weekends.

Exit & Meta

  • Q: “One concrete change we will try in our next release?” They agree on:
  • “last-two-weeks change gate” with explicit owner,
  • “no weekend work” rule without manager approval.
  • Q: “What about this retro felt different, if anything?” Team: more specific, less vague “communication” talk.

docs.title: Recursion notes
docs.text:
What worked:

  • Emotion scaled via simple 1–10 made it safe to talk about support without long stories.
  • Explicit mapping of decision owners turned vague frustration into concrete change.

What felt off:

  • Some quieter team members still spoke less; power dynamics within team persisted.

Space changes (v1.1):

  • Add a written pre-step where people list:
  • “what helped,”
  • “what hurt,”
  • “one rule for next time.”
  • Use anonymous input for sensitive parts if needed.

Space evolved from:

  • “Rough Release Retro v1.0” to
  • “Rough Release Retro – Scope & Support v1.1”.

docs.title: Case 3 – Personal Role Decision: Stay, Shift, or Leave
Context snapshot
docs.text:
• Domain: personal reflection, career.
  • Situation:
  • Senior engineer/lead is considering staying in current role, shifting role internally, or leaving.
  • Not in immediate crisis; more of a long, low-grade tension and curiosity.
  • Format: solo 45-minute journaling session.
  • Stakes: medium-high (career direction, energy, finances).

docs.title: Orientation
docs.text:
“In this Growth-ish personal situation, where I’m considering staying, shifting, or leaving my current role, I want this space to help me understand how my current path aligns with my values, energy, and plausible futures, and to decide on one small, honest next step, in a 45-minute written reflection, staying within work/career and not trying to resolve my entire life story.”

Cognitive goals:

  • distill key fit/misfit points,
  • sketch plausible futures.

Relational (with self) goals:

  • be honest without self-attack,
  • end with a concrete next step, not just rumination.

docs.title: Topology
docs.text:
Dimensions:

  • Value & Impact – what the user wants from work.
  • Emotional & Relational Field / Needs – how current role actually feels.
  • Temporal – past “good fits” and plausible futures.
  • Evidence & Uncertainty – what’s known vs guessed about options.
  • Boundaries & Ownership – what is theirs to change vs not.
  • Meta – short reflection at end.

docs.title: Flow sketch (how it was used)
docs.text:
Value & Impact

  • Prompt:
  • “What do I want my work to give me in the next two to three years?”
  • Writes about:
  • learning and craft,
  • authentic impact on people and systems,
  • enough stability to experiment.

Emotion & Needs

  • Prompt:
  • “On most weeks, does this role feel more energizing or draining? Where exactly?”
  • Identifies:
  • energized by mentoring, systems thinking, and deep technical work.
  • drained by repetitive administrative tasks and misaligned engagements.
  • Needs:
  • autonomy, respect for expertise, meaningful client problems.

Temporal

  • Past:
  • “When did I last feel ‘this is exactly where I should be’?” Writes about a project with high trust and clear mandate.
  • Future:
  • “If I stay and things go reasonably well, what is true?”
  • “If I shift internally?”
  • “If I leave and go independent later?”

Evidence & Uncertainty

  • Known:
  • current org can sometimes provide aligned projects, but not consistently.
  • financial runway is limited; abrupt exit is risky.
  • Assumed:
  • “Other companies will be more aligned,”
  • “Independence means more creative work.”
  • Prompt:
  • “What small experiment could test these assumptions?” Ideas:
  • informal conversations with people in target roles,
  • small side projects or consulting tests.

Boundaries & Ownership

  • Prompt:
  • “What do I own here?” Conversations to start, topics to propose, boundaries on overload.
  • “What does the org own?” Structure, sales model, incentive systems.
  • Realization:
  • some misalignment is structural and unlikely to change soon.

Exit & Meta

  • Prompt:
  • “What feels clearer now?” Clearer that the question is not immediate exit vs stay, but:
    • “How do I prepare for more alignment in 6–18 months?”
  • “What is one small step in the next week?”
    • Plan: schedule a conversation to explore internal shifts,
    • plus define one small external experiment (writing, framing services, portfolio).

docs.title: Recursion notes
docs.text:
What worked:

  • The Temporal layer helped distinguish temporary discomfort from structural misfit.
  • Evidence & Uncertainty prevented premature romanticizing of alternatives.

What felt off:

  • Some emotion around identity and fear surfaced that was heavier than the current scope; needed to pause and not dive deeper.

Space changes (v1.1):

  • Add an explicit Safety note:
  • “If this reflection brings up strong distress or despair, pause and consider external support.”
  • Add a small “identity question” in a controlled way:
  • “What kind of person do I hope I’m becoming through my work?”

docs.title: Case 4 – Live Album Mix Direction: Raw vs Polished
Context snapshot
docs.text:
• Domain: music production.
  • Situation:
  • Band has a multitrack recording of a strong live gig.
  • Debating whether to keep it raw and gig-like or make it closer to a studio album.
  • Format: 60-minute listening session plus 30-minute discussion.
  • Stakes: medium (artistic identity, band satisfaction, listener reception).

docs.title: Orientation
docs.text:
“In this Growth creative situation, where we are deciding how to present our live recording, I want this space to help us choose a direction on the raw ↔ polished spectrum that fits our identity, listeners, and realistic constraints, in a way that feels respectful to performances and honest about what we want, within a 90-minute band session, staying within music/production choices (no career ultimatums, no personal attacks).”

Cognitive goals:

  • decide on mix direction and constraints.

Relational goals:

  • surface hidden preferences,
  • avoid someone quietly hating the final sound.

docs.title: Topology
docs.text:
Dimensions:

  • Contrast & Alternatives – raw vs polished, plus hybrids.
  • Value & Impact – what they want listeners to feel.
  • Emotional & Needs – how each direction feels to band members.
  • Causality & Consequence – future effects on gigs, expectations.
  • Evidence & Uncertainty – history of audience reactions.
  • Layering – song-level vs album-level vs identity.
  • Meta – reflection at the end.

docs.title: Flow sketch (how the conversation ran)
docs.text:
Contrast & Alternatives

  • Listen to:
  • a raw-ish rough mix,
  • a more processed test mix,
  • two reference live albums (one raw, one polished).
  • Q: “If we name the ‘raw’ direction and the ‘studio’ direction, how would we describe each in our own words?”

Value & Impact

  • Q: “What do we most want listeners to feel with this album?” Responses:
  • “like they’re at the gig,”
  • “like we’re better than a casual phone video,”
  • “like we’re a real band worth booking.”
  • Q: “Which matters more for this project:
  • documenting this specific night,
  • or having a calling-card record that represents us?”

Emotion & Needs

  • Q: “How do you personally feel listening to the rougher mix?” Mixed responses:
  • drummer loves energy,
  • vocalist anxious about imperfections.
  • Q: “How do you feel with the more polished version?” Mixed responses:
  • bassist feels it loses some danger,
  • guitarist likes tighter punch.

Causality & Consequence

  • Q: “If we commit to a more polished direction, what happens to:
  • expectations for future gigs,
  • workload for mixing,
  • our own enjoyment?”
  • Q: “If we commit to a more raw direction, what happens to:
  • perception by bookers,
  • listenability on playlists,
  • how we feel about mistakes?”

Evidence & Uncertainty

  • Q: “What do we know from audience reactions at shows?” They recall comments about energy and crowd interaction, not perfection.
  • Q: “Any feedback from previous recordings?” People liked authenticity but sometimes struggled with clarity in noisy environments.
  • Q: “What could we test quickly?” Idea:
  • prepare two versions of one song (raw-leaning and polished-leaning),
  • share privately with small trusted group.

Layering

  • Q: “Are there songs that want more polish and others that can stay messier?” They identify:
  • more melodic songs for extra polish,
  • high-energy rockers for raw treatment.
  • Q: “At album level, what arc do we want between these?”

Exit & Meta

  • Decision:
  • 70/30 direction:
    • overall fidelity and clarity improved,
    • keep count-ins, crowd, some imperfections,
    • only fix clearly painful performance issues.
  • Q: “What about this conversation do we want to remember for future records?” Answer:
  • to decide intent early,
  • to design references and constraints before deep mixing.

docs.title: Recursion notes
docs.text:
What worked:

  • Contrast & Alternatives with listening examples made abstract debate concrete.
  • Emotion & Needs showed where specific members needed reassurance or compromise.

What felt off:

  • Time management; they almost drifted into detailed track-by-track decisions.

Space changes (v1.1):

  • Add a constraint:
  • “No more than 15 minutes discussing specific technical moves; keep focus on direction.”
  • Add a pre-step:
  • each member writes a one-sentence “headline review” of the album they want.

The space evolved from:

  • “Live Mix Direction v1.0” to
  • “Live Mix Direction – Identity First v1.1”.

These four examples are starting points.

As you build your own Question Space System, you’ll gradually create:

  • your own case files,
  • with Orientation, Topology, Flow, and Recursion notes,

tailored to your specific domains, relationships, and style.

This file can grow into a personal case library where you capture:

  • “spaces that worked,”
  • “spaces that failed and why,”
  • and “spaces that changed how I think.”

docs.title: Sources and Inspirations
docs.text:
This system is intentionally personal and synthetic.

It is not a formal academic framework and it does not implement any single external method “by the book”. Instead, it draws from:

  • your own prior frameworks,
  • a cluster of adjacent disciplines and practices,
  • and patterns that repeatedly proved useful in real situations.

This file documents those influences so it’s clear:

  • what QSS is standing on,
  • what it is not claiming to be,
  • and where further reading or attribution might be appropriate.

docs.title: Purpose of this file
docs.text:
• Make intellectual lineage visible and honest.
  • Avoid unintentional plagiarism or “mystery origins”.
  • Give you anchors if you want to:
  • credit inspirations in public materials,
  • deepen specific lines of thinking later,
  • or point others to related work (“if you like QSS, you might also explore…”).

This is a living list. You can extend it as you notice new connections.

docs.title: Primary Internal Sources
docs.text: These are your own frameworks and artifacts that QSS is most directly shaped by.

docs.title: Human Cooperation System (HCS)
docs.text:
Influence:

  • Orientation:
  • attention to conditions, needs, functions, and modes.
  • Explicit power and safety awareness.
  • Focus on system modes:
  • Setup,
  • Stabilization,
  • Growth,
  • Conflict/Reset (QSS currently uses the first three explicitly).
  • Function-first thinking:
  • “What function are we trying to restore or enable?”

Echoes in QSS:

  • Mode model (Setup / Stabilization / Growth).
  • Emphasis on conditions (emotional, relational, structural) as part of Orientation.
  • Recursion as a system-maintaining function, not just a “nice extra”.

docs.title: 3-in-3 SDLC Framework (3SF)
docs.text:
Influence:

  • Multi-sided view:
  • client, vendor, product/value relationships.
  • Contract/tool thinking:
  • engagement patterns, boundary agreements, decision clarity.
  • Maturity and state tracking:
  • where a project sits on axes like value, flow, shared ownership.

Echoes in QSS:

  • Boundaries & Ownership dimension.
  • Value & Impact as a first-class dimension rather than implicit.
  • Domain playbooks for software delivery and consulting.

docs.title: Couple / Relationship Framework (CLRF / “Between Us”)
docs.text:
Influence:

  • Conditions/needs language for relational dynamics.
  • Emotional scope boundaries:
  • what is safe to handle in a structured conversation vs what requires deeper support.
  • Focus on everyday cooperation rather than extreme crisis only.

Echoes in QSS:

  • Emotional & Relational Field / Needs dimension.
  • Explicit “scope and limits” section (what QSS is not for).
  • Personal reflection playbooks (role decision, burnout, recurring conflict).

docs.title: Adjacent Practices and Disciplines
docs.text: These are areas where QSS is philosophically aligned or structurally inspired, but not a direct implementation.

docs.title: Systems Thinking and Organizational Diagnostics
docs.text:
Influence:

  • Seeing problems as patterns and feedback loops, not isolated events.
  • Shifting focus from “who failed?” to “what system produces this outcome?”
  • Using multiple “views” and layers (individual, team, org, ecosystem).

Echoes in QSS:

  • Layering / Abstraction dimension.
  • Causality & Consequence dimension (cause–effect chains).
  • Recursion as a way for the system (not the individual) to learn.

docs.title: Coaching and Facilitation Practices
docs.text:
Influence:

  • Coaching-style questioning:
  • curiosity,
  • non-judgment,
  • focus on client’s own insight.
  • Workshop facilitation patterns:
  • check-ins,
  • retrospectives,
  • decision framing.

Echoes in QSS:

  • Meta / Reflexive dimension:
  • checking “how is this conversation working?”
  • Templates for:
  • entry questions,
  • exit/next-step questions.
  • Emphasis on “one small step” instead of grand plans.

Important distinction:

  • QSS borrows structural ideas (how to hold a conversation),
  • but does not position itself as a coaching certification or therapy method.

docs.title: Conflict Resolution and Nonviolent Communication (NVC-like patterns)
docs.text:
Influence:

  • Separating:
  • observations,
  • feelings,
  • needs,
  • and requests.
  • Treating needs as universal and legitimate, even when strategies conflict.
  • De-escalation through naming impact rather than blaming.

Echoes in QSS:

  • Emotional & Relational Field / Needs dimension.
  • Patterns that ask:
  • “How does this feel?”,
  • “Which needs are met/not met?”,
  • framed within current context.
  • Stabilization-mode spaces that explicitly ask:
  • how collaboration feels,
  • and what would make it more workable.

Boundary:

  • QSS keeps emotional work:
  • context-bound,
  • present/future-oriented,
  • and explicitly non-clinical.

docs.title: Agile / Lean / DevOps / Retro Practices
docs.text:
Influence:

  • Iterative improvement and “inspect and adapt”.
  • Retrospectives (what went well, what didn’t, what to change).
  • Hypothesis and experiment framing:
  • treat change as testable bets.

Echoes in QSS:

  • Recursion and iteration loops chapter.
  • Evidence & Uncertainty dimension:
  • “what do we know vs assume?”
  • “what experiment could reduce uncertainty?”
  • Growth-mode spaces for DevEx, delivery practice, and creative improvement.

docs.title: Strategy and Sensemaking Frameworks
docs.text:
Influence:

  • Strategy as a pattern of choices under uncertainty.
  • Mapping value chains and evolution (for example, Wardley Maps-style thinking in your broader work).
  • Frameworks that separate:
  • context,
  • climate,
  • doctrine,
  • and gameplay.

Echoes in QSS:

  • Value & Impact, Evidence & Uncertainty, and Contrast & Alternatives working together as a strategic lens.
  • Orientation as a “mini strategy statement” for each space.
  • Domain playbooks that align question spaces with strategic outcomes (delivery models, creative direction).

QSS is not a strategy framework by itself, but it is strategy-compatible: it gives you a way to interrogate strategic choices.

docs.title: Critical Thinking and Rationalist Traditions
docs.text:
Influence:

  • Making assumptions explicit.
  • Separating belief from evidence.
  • Thinking in “confidence levels” and update rules.

Echoes in QSS:

  • Evidence & Uncertainty dimension:
  • “what do we actually know?”
  • “how could we be wrong?”
  • Question patterns around experiments and falsification.
  • Avoiding overconfident narratives, especially in high-stakes decisions.

docs.title: AI, Prompting, and Question Engineering
docs.text:
QSS is also informed by:

  • your experience working with GPT-style systems as:
  • assistants,
  • co-writers,
  • and diagnostic agents (HCS GPT, 3SF GPT, future QSS GPT).
  • observation that:
  • “the quality of answers is bounded by the quality of questions + context.”

Influence:

  • Treating “question space” as a design artifact, not an accident.
  • Thinking about:
  • Orientation,
  • Topology,
  • Flow,
  • Recursion, as the “system prompt” for human–human and human–AI dialogues alike.
  • Using templates and checklists similar to prompt-engineering patterns:
  • explicit roles,
  • constraints,
  • modes.

Echoes in QSS:

  • Structure of files (Theory → Practice → Reference) mirrors how you’ve built domain-specific GPTs.
  • Emphasis on:
  • context intake,
  • explicit modes,
  • reusable patterns, in both human and AI-assisted workflows.

docs.title: Philosophical and Historical Echoes
docs.text: These are not direct sources you systematically studied for QSS, but conceptual echoes worth naming.

docs.title: Socratic and Inquiry-Based Traditions
docs.text:
Influence:

  • Using questions to surface hidden assumptions.
  • Leading someone to see a contradiction or gap in their own reasoning.
  • Emphasis on understanding “what is really meant” rather than just the first answer.

Echoes in QSS:

  • Clarification and Assumptions dimensions working in tandem.
  • Meta questions that ask:
  • “Have we named the real issue, or are we circling?”

docs.title: Dialogue and Deliberation Traditions
docs.text:
Influence:

  • Structured dialogue aiming at mutual understanding, not just winning.
  • Techniques that:
  • slow down reaction,
  • foreground listening.

Echoes in QSS:

  • Multi-perspective entry questions:
  • “From your perspective, what is happening?”
  • Domain playbooks that ask:
  • client, vendor, internal roles to describe their views before designing solutions.

docs.title: What QSS Explicitly Is Not
docs.text:
To avoid over-claiming or confusion, QSS is not:

  • A therapy modality.
  • A coaching school or certification.
  • A replacement for:
  • legal advice,
  • medical or mental health care,
  • HR or safeguarding processes.
  • A direct implementation of:
  • Nonviolent Communication,
  • Wardley Maps,
  • Cynefin,
  • any specific Agile scaling framework,
  • or any particular philosophical school.

It borrows structural ideas and sensibilities, not protocols.

When QSS touches issues that clearly belong to those domains, its intended behavior is to:

  • recognize the boundary,
  • not cross it,
  • and suggest more appropriate forms of help.

docs.title: How to Extend This Sources List
docs.text:
You can expand this file as you:

  • notice new influences (“this dimension feels like X”),
  • read new material that sharpens your thinking,
  • or want to credit specific authors or works.

Simple pattern for adding entries:

### [Name of model / author / field]

Influence:

- …

Echoes in QSS:

- …

Boundary / distinction:

- what QSS does not claim or copy from this source.

You can also maintain a private version with: • specific books, articles, talks, or courses, • and any notes on “what I borrowed, what I changed, what I rejected”.

Why this matters

QSS is ultimately about honest inquiry.

Being transparent about its sources is part of that honesty: • It keeps your work grounded and credit-aware. • It helps others relate QSS to concepts they already know. • It reminds you that this system is not magic: • it’s your synthesis of things you’ve lived, studied, and tested.

This file exists so that as QSS grows, its roots stay visible.
